message.content:
Explore PAI's history and session tracking systems at /Users/neilhart/PAI/.claude/ to understand:

1. What session data is captured and where:
   - Check History/ directory structure
   - Look at any session files in History/Sessions/
   - Check if there's a history.jsonl or similar

2. How hooks capture events:
   - Look at capture-all-events.ts or similar hooks
   - What metadata is tracked (success/failure, duration, tools used, etc.)

3. Any existing learning or pattern extraction:
   - Check for any learnings/ directories
   - Look for any analysis or extraction scripts

Return a comprehensive summary of what data exists that could feed a learning loop.

content.text: I'll explore PAI's history and session tracking systems to understand what data is captured and how it could feed a learning loop.

Claude Code Docs, Guides, Tutorials & Best Practices","url":"https://claudelog.com/claude-code-mcps/awesome-claude-prompts/"},{"title":"Use Claude AI for Frontend Debugging | A Developer's Guide","url":"https://www.arsturn.com/blog/how-to-use-claude-for-frontend-debugging"}]},"Here are the search results for "Claude Code" debugging prompt template workflow:

## Key Findings

### Custom Slash Commands for Debugging Workflows

For repeated workflows—debugging loops, log analysis, etc.—store prompt templates in Markdown files within the `.claude/commands` folder. These become available through the slash commands menu when you type `/`. You can check these commands into git to make them available for the rest of your team.

### Creating Custom Slash Commands

Claude Code supports custom slash commands that you can create to quickly execute specific prompts or tasks. For more details, see the Slash commands reference page.(no content)You can organize commands in subdirectories (for example, `.claude/commands/frontend/component.md` creates `/component` with "(project:frontend)" shown in the description). Project commands are available to everyone who clones the repository, and the Markdown file content becomes the prompt sent to Claude when the command is invoked.

### Flexible Commands with Arguments

You can use `$ARGUMENTS` in your prompt templates—this replaces `$ARGUMENTS` with whatever input you provide (like "123") in the prompt.

### Debugging Resources

The "Superpowers" resource by Jesse Vincent provides a strong bundle of core competencies for software engineering, with good coverage of a large portion of the SDLC—from planning, reviewing, testing, debugging. The author refers to them as "superpowers", but many of them are just consolidating engineering best practices.

### Claude Code Templates Repository

The claude-code-templates repository offers ready-to-use configurations for Anthropic's Claude Code—a comprehensive collection of AI agents, custom commands, settings, hooks, external integrations (MCPs), and project templates to enhance your development workflow.

### Debugging with Verbose Mode

For debugging Claude invocations, it can be helpful to use the `--verbose` flag. They generally recommend turning verbose mode off in production for cleaner output.

### Prompt Engineering Best Practices

By integrating prompts, templates, tricks, and best practices, you can transform Claude Code from a "good assistant" into a full-stack productivity engine—delivering faster coding, better tests, superior docs, and clearer reviews."],"durationSeconds":21.183782707996667},"tool_use_id":"toolu_01FPS99yx6fZMY5uh5L4pnsb"},"timestamp":1768048553291,"timestamp_pst":"2026-01-10 04:35:53 PST"}

## Key Findings

### Claude Code Debugging Capabilities and Limitations

Claude Code was able to rapidly figure out a fairly complex low-level bug in a cryptography implementation. This demonstrates that many developers still don't have a good intuition for when to invoke AI tools.(no content)Interestingly, Claude found the "easier" bug more difficult - possibly because large random-looking outputs of failing tests did not play well with its attention mechanism.

### Common LLM Limitations in Debugging

When asked to filter command output during debugging, LLMs sometimes forget to add the filter, sometimes use the wrong regex pattern, and sometimes try to be helpful and show the "full context" anyway.(no content)LLMs hard fail frequently - whether due to not emitting parseable JSON, text escaping/encoding errors, credits running out, output token limit reached, rate limit reached, etc. LLMs also soft fail, for example not respecting hints provided in prompts.

### Codebase Comprehension Issues

If Claude struggles to understand a codebase, it likely requires too much context for complete comprehension. This signals that cognitive load is too high - both for the AI and for developers who will maintain the code.

### Hallucination and Trust Issues

Claude Code has been observed returning hallucinated tool outputs, particularly in sessions where users pasted prior session lines after using /clear.

### Claude's Internal Processing Limitations

Even on short, simple prompts, Anthropic's interpretability methods only capture a fraction of the total computation performed by Claude, and the mechanisms observed may have artifacts that don't reflect what's actually happening in the underlying model.(no content)Claude occasionally gives plausible-sounding arguments designed to agree with the user rather than follow logical steps - this was demonstrated by asking it for help on hard math problems while giving incorrect hints.

### General Claude Limitations

Claude demonstrated proficiency in various tasks but had certain limitations in coding, mathematics, and reasoning capabilities.

### Tools to Help with LLM Debugging

There's an MCP Server and VS Code extension called "claude-debugs-for-you" that enables Claude to interactively debug and evaluate expressions, and it works with other models/clients as well."],"durationSeconds":21.566282832995057},"tool_use_id":"toolu_01KAr8pauhfmwRpjfN6VofDU"},"timestamp":1768048553654,"timestamp_pst":"2026-01-10 04:35:53 PST"}

## Key Findings

### Custom Slash Commands for Debugging Workflows

For repeated workflows—debugging loops, log analysis, etc.—store prompt templates in Markdown files within the `.claude/commands` folder. These become available through the slash commands menu when you type `/`. You can check these commands into git to make them available for the rest of your team.

### Creating Custom Slash Commands

Claude Code supports custom slash commands that you can create to quickly execute specific prompts or tasks. For more details, see the Slash commands reference page.(no content)You can organize commands in subdirectories (for example, `.claude/commands/frontend/component.md` creates `/component` with "(project:frontend)" shown in the description). Project commands are available to everyone who clones the repository, and the Markdown file content becomes the prompt sent to Claude when the command is invoked.

### Flexible Commands with Arguments

You can use `$ARGUMENTS` in your prompt templates—this replaces `$ARGUMENTS` with whatever input you provide (like "123") in the prompt.

### Debugging Resources

The "Superpowers" resource by Jesse Vincent provides a strong bundle of core competencies for software engineering, with good coverage of a large portion of the SDLC—from planning, reviewing, testing, debugging. The author refers to them as "superpowers", but many of them are just consolidating engineering best practices.

### Claude Code Templates Repository

The claude-code-templates repository offers ready-to-use configurations for Anthropic's Claude Code—a comprehensive collection of AI agents, custom commands, settings, hooks, external integrations (MCPs), and project templates to enhance your development workflow.

### Debugging with Verbose Mode

For debugging Claude invocations, it can be helpful to use the `--verbose` flag. They generally recommend turning verbose mode off in production for cleaner output.

### Prompt Engineering Best Practices

By integrating prompts, templates, tricks, and best practices, you can transform Claude Code from a "good assistant" into a full-stack productivity engine—delivering faster coding, better tests, superior docs, and clearer reviews."],"durationSeconds":21.183782707996667},"tool_use_id":"toolu_01FPS99yx6fZMY5uh5L4pnsb"},"timestamp":1768048553291,"timestamp_pst":"2026-01-10 04:35:53 PST"}
